figure.ab: N.W. Bolster & Co Court Stenographies 707-08 Lowman Bldg Please, Elliot 2B Seattle

div1.p: In the United States District Court, Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the matter of the application for a writ of habeas corpus for Gwoo Shee Ah Look } No. 2647.

This matter coming on for hearing on this 29th day of April, 1914, at the hour of 10:00 o'clock a.m. before the Honorable Jeremiah Neterer, Judge of the above entitled court, the following proceedings were had:

figure.ab: N.W. Bolster & Co Court Stenographies 707-08 Lowman Bldg Please, Elliot 2B Seattle

div1.p: A.L. Clark, being first duly sworn, testifies as follows:
Q (Mr. Wilbur) What is your name and occupation?
A A.L. Clark is my name and I am an attorney.
Q You are connected with the firm of Wilbur and Spencer of Portland?
A I am.
Q And how long have you been practicing law?
A Eighteen years.
Q Were you called upon in the early part of November, Mr. Clark, relative to looking after the interstate of Gwoo Shee At Look, the petitioner in this case?
A I was
Q I wish you would state to the court the entire transaction briefly, and as clearly as you can from the time you first learned of it and particular of anuy talks you may have had with Mr. Barbour.
The Court: The only thing I care to know about is what relations you sustained to the Commissioner's office in Portland, as to whether the office knew that you were attorney for the woman.

A (by the witness) On the 5th day of November, some time before noon, the matter was called to my attention and I went down to the police station where the women were then confined, and Mr. Barbour was there. I first applied to the policemen to ascertain if I could see the people.
The Court: What people -- what do you mean by "the people"?

A (Continuing) Well, this Chinese woman, and I was 1
k3
N.W. Bolster & Co Court Stenographies 707-08 Lowman Bldg Please, Elliot 2B Seattle referred to Mr. Barbour, and I went upstairs where he was and enquired of him if he had this woman there, and he said that he did, and I then inquired if I could see her and have a talk with her, and I told him that the firm of Wilbur and Spencer, in connection with me, had been employed to look after her interest. He said to me that he was just going through with them and taking their statements and that no one could see them at that time, and if I could come around some time later on, or come to his office I could probably get to see this woman. On the next day, I believe it was, I went to his office in the Railway Exchange Building, on the same mission, and he then told me that at that time I could not see the woman. I was somewhat ignorant of the manner of proceedings in the matter of this kind, and he gave me a whole lot of information and told me the way in which such examination were conducted, and that they were conducted secretly until a certain point when it was deemed proper by the Commissioner to advise the woman that she was entitled to an attorney, if she so desired, and at that time I asked him if I could see the woman, who then had been transferred to the county jail, but was not permitted to do so. I think from that time on, almost every day, probably not every day, I either saw him in person or had a talk with him on the 'phone -- we had numerous talks over the 'phone relative to this woman. Before her statement had been taken I called him up and made inquiries and he said "We will put you down as atttoneys and at the proper time you will be permitted to come in and see the record". 2
k4
N.W. Bolster & Co Court Stenographies 707-08 Lowman Bldg Please, Elliot 2B Seattle After her statement had been taken, but before the two policemen's statement, or testimony, had been taken I was permitted to see her in the county jail on an order from Mr. Barbour to the jailer directing the jailer to permit me to toalk to the woman and to take an interpreter in-, I went there -- I did not known whne the testimony of the two policemen was to be taken and I did not know the names of any of the witnesses until after their testimony had been taken, when Mr. Barbour handed to me the record which contained the statementsof Gwoo Shee Ah Look and the two policemen.
Q You said that Mr. Barbour gave you this order to see the woman?
A Yes sir
q After her statement had been taken?
A After her statement had been taken.
Q But before the testimony of the other witnesses.

A But before the testimony of the two policemen, because he said at that time that he still had some other testimony to take in this case, and that he had been quite busy with some other matters and had not concluded yet, but he had a couple of other witnesses, and when that was taken the record would be complete.
Q And then the record here shows that this testimony was taken, I believe, upon the 17th, of the policemen.
A Yes sir.
Q And when was the first opportunity that you had is any way of seeing this record or knowing anything about what was being taken?

A The first opportunity that I had was after all the 3
k5
N.W. Bolster & Co Court Stenographies 707-08 Lowman Bldg Please, Elliot 2B Seattle testimony was taken, when Mr. Barbour handed to me a transcript of Gwoo Shee Ah Look's testimony, and a transcript of the testimony of the two policemen.
Q And what did he say at that time?

A He handed the record to me; I think called me up on the 'phone and said "That you can prepare such -- present such evidence as you now have by way of affidavits and I will send them with my report to the Secretary of Commerce and Labor".
Mr. Wilbur: That is all -- do you desire to ask any questions, Mr. Fishburn?
Mr. Fishburn: That is all.
Mr. Wilbur: Mr. Fishburn, would you care to put Mr. Barbour on the stand?

Mr. Fishburn: I believe that is in substance the facts in the case; that is, I mean his statement there seems to be in substance correct, but I will ask Mr. Barbour to take the stand a moment and ask him one question or two.

figure.ab: N.W. Bolster & Co Court Stenographies 707-08 Lowman Bldg Please, Elliot 2B Seattle

div1.p: J.H. Barbour, being first duly sworn, testifies as follows:
Mr. Fishburn: However, I believe this would waive my objection, and I don't want to do that -- you need not take the stand.
The Court: So far as I am concerned you can have it in the record without waiving your objection, and we will have his testimony in.
Mr. Fishburne: All right.
Mr. Wilbur: We will make absolutely no objection. We want the court to understand the situation and we are perfectly willing that the record shall show that -- we will make no objection.
The Court: You might just say that by offering this evidence you do not desire to waive your objection.

Mr. Fishburn: In offering it I desire the record to show that I do not desire to waive my objection. My objection is that the record is the only thing that the court has the right to examine even as to the question of employing attorney.

Q I desire, Mr. Barbour, to ask you whether, before taking the testimony of the policemen, there had been any record made -- what, if any, record had been made in your office as to the attorney there, before you took the testimony of the policemen after you had taken her testimony?

A There had been no formal entry or recongition of the atttorney at any particular time whatsoever. Atttorneys for all these cases come into my office an hour after 5 k7
N.W. Bolster & Co Court Stenographies 707-08 Lowman Bldg Please, Elliot 2B Seattle the hearing take place, a ssuming to represent these people; most of them being reputable atttorneys I naturally would recongize their appearance in the case, but not admit them in the case until such time as I see fit, under the regulations. The recognition was not an admission in this case, however.
Q How soon after the testimony was taken did you notify them of their rights to appear?

A I had had numerous talks with Mr. Clark, and as he states, concerning his rights in the case and the limitation on his rights, I told him that as soon as I had taken the testimony of the woman and certain other evidence he would be admitted to the case, as the regulations provided. He understood that.
Q Did you tell him that he would have the right to cross examine the witnesses?
A I never told him that, never.
Did you make that clear to him that --

A The matter of cross examining witnesses was never mentioned by him no by me either. Mr. Clark, as he states, was ignorant of this procedure and I enlightened him along this line and I told him what his rights were, and he accepted my word; he accepted my statement of it as being correct.
Q Am I understand the practice pursued in Portland, what is that as to the presence of attorneys while the Government is taking the testimony; what has been the practice there?

Mr. Wilbur: I might make the formal objection that I think that is governed by the rules and construction of the 6 k8
N.W. Bolster & Co Court Stenographies 707-08 Lowman Bldg Please, Elliot 2B Seattle law on the subject.
The Court: I don't think the custom in Portland would govern.
Cross Examination
Q (Mr. Wilbur) Without going into the various questions here; you heard Mr. Clark's testimony and his statement here?
A Yes, sir.
Q And that statement, as you understand it, is substantially correct?
A Well, I would not want to admit it all as being correct. I admit Mr. Clark appeared at the police station on the day of the arrest.
Q She was arrested on the 4th?
A Yes, sir, and I remember Mr. Clark appeared the same day.
Q And Mr. Clark saw you frequently, didn't he, up to the time?
A He called me up concerning it.
Q --up to the time that the record was finally completed and turned over to him.
A Yes, he did
Q And, as a matter of fact, you refused Mr. Clark, didn't you, the right to attend any of these examinations.
A Mr. Clark never demanded it as a right or a privilege.
Q Did you ever tell him that he had any right to come there and appear as an attorney?

A I told Mr. Clark at the beginning, when he expressed ignorance of the regulations, that he would be admitted 7
k9
N.W. Bolster & Co Court Stenographies 707-08 Lowman Bldg Please, Elliot 2B Seattle after I had taken the testimony of this alien and had secured certain other evidence -- I would notify =him and he would then be admitted in the case and have access to the record and to that testimony, and would be permissted to submit such evidence as he desired.
Q In other words, you practically told him, did you not, that he would not be allowed to be present until after that time.
A Until such time as I would designate.
Q Did you ever designate or indicate to him that he had the right to attend any of these hearings -- you never did did you?
A What do you mean by "hearings"?
Q You just said you told him that he could come in whenever you designated to him a time; now, as a matter of fact, you never did designate to him any time?
A I did.
Q When?
A By giving him a copyof the record.
Q And that was on what date?
A I don't recall
Q It was after you had taken the statements of the policemen, wasn't it?
A Yes sir, it was.
Q And you had taken Gwoo Shee Ah Look's testimony, as shown on the record, on the 10th?
A I believe so.
Q And the record is true, that the policemen's testimony was taken on the 17th?
A Yes sir.

figure.ab: N.W. Bolster & Co Court Stenographies 707-08 Lowman Bldg Please, Elliot 2B Seattle

div1.p: Q Did you, between the 10th and the 17th, indicate to Mr. Clark in any way, shape, manner or form that he could come in, and as the attorney for the woman attend that hearing of the policemen when their testimony was being taken.
A I did not.
Q Or by cross examination?

A I did not. Mr. Clark, if he so considers he was admitted, was admitted for the purpose of bailing this woman out. By reason of pressure of buisness I had been compelled to hold this woman, and several others, in jail for a week. It would have been necessary to have held them for another week if I had kept Mr. Clark out of the case entirely until the statements of these policemen were taken. I admitted him to the case for the purpose of bailing this woman out, but for no other purpose, until the statements of the police were taken.
Q That was after the hearing was concluded?
A No--
Q After the statement of the policemen?
A After the statement from the woman.
Q Now, you gave to Mr. Clark, didn't you, written authority to see this woman between the 10th and and the 17th?
A Well, if she ws to be bailed out it would be natural he should see her.
Q Please answer my question, did you or did you not?
A Certainly, for the purpose of bailing her out.
Q Now, at the hearing, when the policemen's statements were taken, this woman not present, was she?

figure.ab: N.W. Bolster & Co Court Stenographies 707-08 Lowman Bldg Please, Elliot 2B Seattle

div1.p: A No sir; she don't speak the English language.
Q She was not present?
A She was not present.
Q Neither was Mr. Clark present?
A Mr. Clark was not present.
Q Nor was any member of our firm present?
A They were not present.
Q Nor was any member of our firm notified that this hearing was going to be had of those policemen at that time?
A Not at this particular time or place or presence.
Q Neither was this woman notified that his hearing was to go on at this time?
A The hearing of the officers?
Q The taking of the testimony of the two officers.
A This Chinese woman?
Q Yes.
A No sir, she was not notified.
Q It was taken without any invitation to her whatever?
A Exactly.
Q Or to any member of our firm?
A Yes.
Mr. Wilbur: That is all the testimony, may it please Your Honor, that we desire to offer.
